learnings.title: Directness, Power Distance, and Context
learnings.bodyMd:
# Directness, Power Distance, and Context

## Overview
Cultural norms vary in directness, hierarchy, and reliance on shared context. Adapt your style to reduce friction.

## Key Concepts
- Low vs. high context communication.
- Power distance: deference and decision patterns.
- Direct vs. indirect feedback norms.

## Examples
- In high‑context settings, provide more backstory and read implicit cues.
- In low‑context, get to the point and request explicit decisions.

## Common Pitfalls
- Reading indirectness as evasiveness.
- Mistaking deference for agreement.

## Summary
Observe and adapt to context and hierarchy norms. Make your intent explicit and verify understanding across styles.

learnings.title: Time Orientation and Scheduling Norms
learnings.bodyMd:
# Time Orientation and Scheduling Norms

## Overview
Perceptions of time vary: punctuality, deadlines, and long‑ vs short‑term focus differ across cultures.

## Key Concepts
- Monochronic vs. polychronic time.
- Deadline rigidity vs. flexibility.
- Planning horizons and holiday calendars.

## Examples
- Buffer schedules for polychronic cultures.
- Clarify what "deadline" means explicitly.

## Common Pitfalls
- Assigning moral weight to time styles.
- Hidden holiday conflicts.

## Summary
Negotiate timing norms openly. Add buffers and explicit definitions to reduce missed expectations.

learnings.title: Feedback and Face‑Saving Across Cultures
learnings.bodyMd:
# Feedback and Face‑Saving Across Cultures

## Overview
Deliver feedback in ways that preserve dignity and encourage improvement across different norms.

## Key Concepts
- Indirect feedback: soften with context and suggestions.
- Private vs. public recognition.
- Face‑saving mechanisms and shared blame language.

## Examples
- Use "could we try" phrasing and joint problem statements.
- Recognize teams rather than individuals where appropriate.

## Common Pitfalls
- Public critique causing shame.
- Sarcasm or humor that doesn’t translate.

## Summary
Tailor feedback tone and setting to local norms. Protect face and emphasize joint improvement.

learnings.title: Building Cross‑Cultural Empathy
learnings.bodyMd:
# Building Cross‑Cultural Empathy

## Overview
Curiosity and humility accelerate cross‑cultural collaboration. Learn local norms and language cues.

## Key Concepts
- Cultural briefings and buddy systems.
- Language accommodations and plain English.
- Ask‑observe‑adapt loop.

## Examples
- Pair newcomers with local mentors.
- Maintain a team glossary of idioms and acronyms.

## Common Pitfalls
- Assuming "global English" solves nuance.
- Token gestures without real learning.

## Summary
Invest in learning norms and language. Ask thoughtful questions and adapt quickly based on feedback and observation.

learnings.title: Working Agreements for Global Teams
learnings.bodyMd:
# Working Agreements for Global Teams

## Overview
Explicit working agreements reduce friction across cultures and time zones.

## Key Concepts
- Core hours and response SLAs.
- Decision and documentation norms.
- Meeting rotation and inclusivity practices.

## Examples
- Rotate inconvenient meeting times.
- Document decisions in a shared, searchable place.

## Common Pitfalls
- Unwritten rules that exclude remote members.
- One‑time zones dominating.

## Summary
Codify inclusive norms so collaboration doesn’t depend on guessing local expectations.
